EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

    Overview 
The Liverpool Wastewater Treatment Plant is a 15 million gallon per day facility that removes pollutants from municipal sewage prior to discharging the clean water to the West Branch of the Rocky River. As a last step in the treatment of the wastewater, chlorine is added to kill any remaining bacteria. The chlorine used in this process is purchased in one-ton cylinders. Typically six (6) cylinders are stored in a chlorination building specifically designed for this purpose. Two (2) of the cylinders are in use and connected to the chlorination system while four (4) are waiting to be used. All cylinders are contained in a concrete block building with a pre-cast concrete roof to minimize any possibility of fire in the building. Fire alarms have been installed and have been connected to the plant wide computer system. The cylinders are stored on appropriate concrete saddles on a concrete floor. No other materials are stored in the building. A wind sock has been installed on top of the building to determine the wind direction. A chlorine leak detection alarm and chlorine detector levels are displayed on a plant wide computer system.. System is maintained and checked on a routine basis in accordance with plant internal preventative maintenance program.  

    Chlorine Accidental Release and Emergency Response Policies 
The Administration at the Liverpool Wastewater Treatment Plant. in conjunction with plant operators, chlorine supplier, and The Valley City Fire Department have developed suggested operating procedures (SOP??A?s) for the handling of the chlorination facilities. These procedures outline in detail how cylinders are connected to the chlorine feed system, the number of personnel (including observers) to be involved in the changing of the cylinders, the frequency at which chlorine piping and valves are to be replaced, etc. All operators are trained to know the SOP??A?s and this training is reviewed quarterly and during safety meetings.

This training is evaluated by using written exams and individual audits. This document and all information is accessible on a plant wide web site that can be obtained by all personnel on any given day. All procedures have been continually revised by using the Process Hazard Analysis Procedures.  

The Liverpool Wastewater Treatment Plant Administration along with the Medina County Sanitary Engineers Safety Coordinator and County Local Emergency Planning Commission (LEPC), have developed a spill response document known as the Chlorine Spill Investigative/Response Procedure. This document provides step-by-step instruction regarding steps to be taken when responding to a chlorine leak. In 2006 an internal worse case scenario SOP was created in conjunction with The Valley City Fire Department to train emergency response and plant personnel. 

    Worst Case/Alternate Release Scenario 
As part of this plan, a worst case and a more likely alternative release scenario has been documented. The worst-case release scenario calls for the release of the entire content of one cylinder in ten minutes. The cylinders are constructed of one-inch thick steel with recessed fill/discharge valves making the possibility of the loss of the entire contents of one tank within this time period remote. The alternative release is considered to be a more likely scenario of how a release would occur. In this scenario we have considered that a pipe has broken or a valve has failed leaving a one square inch hole from which the chlorine can escape. The plant alarm has sounded but it has taken 10  minutes for an operator or the fire department to don their SCBA and HAZMAT suit and enter the building and secure the leak. 

Modeling for the worst scenario was conducted using the RMP*Comp software. This scenario assumed a wind speed of 3.4 mph and a temperature of 77 degrees Fahrenheit during a  loss of the entire contents of a full tank. This program indicated that Toxic Endpoint is 0.9 miles. The conce

ntration is 0.0087 mg/l. The zone of influence for the worst case  scenario existed with a 0.9 mile radius of the treatment plant. 

Modeling for the alternative release scenario was also conducted using the RMP*Comp  software. This scenario assumes a wind speed of 6.7 mph and a temperature of 77 degrees Fahrenheit during a  loss of the entire contents of a full tank. The variables that we entered into the RMP* Comp program included a tank pressure of 130 psi, and the tank temperature was 92 degrees Fahrenheit which was the highest recorded temperature for our area in the last three years. This program indicated that Toxic Endpoint is 0.2   miles. The concentration is 0.0087 mg/l. The zone of influence for the alternative case scenario existed with a  0.2  mile radius of the treatment plant.

Land View 6 was used to determine the population effected within the 0.9 and 0.2 mile radius. It was determined that the release affected 383 people for the worst case and 4 people for the alternative scenario. 

    Five-Year Accident History
There have been no chlorine related accidents or incidents reported in the last five years.

    Emergency Response Program and Planned Improvements 
As indicated previously, Medina County has collaborated with the LEPC to develop a release response program. Written procedures are readily available to plant operators on the plant wide computer system that include this document and our complete chlorine RMP program. Included are all of our SOP training, preventative maintenance, power point documentation, and reference information history. Steps to be taken during a release, entities to be contacted and the telephone numbers for those entities are also  
contained in this document. Personnel at the plant are given training regarding the response procedures and refreshers are completed periodically during the plant safety meetings. 

In April 9, 2007 the local fire department conducted a mock emergency training exercise involving plant personnel

at the wastewater treatment plant. The mock emergency was designed to simulate a major chlorine leak scenario. Special attention was given to our major leak SOP. We followed the steps outlined and made necessary modifications.   These efforts along with safety operating procedures already in place will minimize the possibility for leaks and minimize response times in the event a leak does occur. This will result in a safe working environment and the protection of the local community. 

    Process Hazard Analysis
On September 6, 2006 we had a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) meeting where we identified that the changing of the cylinders produced the greatest potential hazard of a release of chlorine gas. Four separate hazards were identified by the team. 

On September 27, 2006 another meeting was held to discuss the resolutions and implementation of solutions. On December 13, 2006 we concluded our PHA by reviewing all the changes that we had made. We made all the information about these changes available on the plant web site. 

On March 4, 2009 another PHA meeting was held where the team revisited the past consequence release scenarios, the team felt that changing the cylinders was still the condition that posed the greatest possible hazard. During this meeting the team revisited the four cylinder changing issues and added concerns about building fire or unsafe building temperatures. During this meeting a RMP to do list was created. The minutes of this meeting are located on the plant web site for review by the plant operators. A follow-up meeting was held on April 8. 2009, to review the progress of these required changes, the majority of these items on the to do list were completed. A third follow-up meeting is scheduled for July 8, 2009. 

    Hoist Maintenance
We have had annual inspections on the chlorine cylinder hoist. The last one was completed by All Ohio Crane Inc. during March 2009. This inspection produced several improvement suggestions that we are currently im

plementing. We have also modified our  preventative maintenance program, and created a hoist maintenance SOP to improve on our regular hoist maintenance. The annual inspection results and the regular hoist maintenance documentation is maintained on our web site for the operators to review.

    Chlorination System Preventative Maintenance
We have created detailed power point presentations as our SOP's for our preventative 
maintenance procedures for the chlorination system. These include instructions for the complete rebuilding of chlorine regulators, piping inspections, chlorine sensors and alarm systems. All of this information is available to all the operators through the plant wide web site, including a complete history of all the preventative maintenance that has been scheduled and completed.
